Name: PHENFORMIN
Description: Phenformin is a member of the class of biguanides that is biguanide in which one of the terminal nitrogen atoms is substituted by a 2-phenylethyl group. It was used as an anti-diabetic drug but was later withdrawn from the market due to potential risk of lactic acidosis. It has a role as an antineoplastic agent, a geroprotector and a hypoglycemic agent. It is functionally related to a biguanide.

logP.References: Hansch, C., Leo, A., D. Hoekman. Exploring QSAR - Hydrophobic, Electronic, and Steric Constants. Washington, DC: American Chemical Society., 1995., p. 78

mechanism_of_action.References: Goodman, L.S., and A. Gilman. (eds.) The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics. 5th ed. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co., Inc., 1975., p. 1524
mechanism_of_action.Value: IN VITRO, PHENFORMIN, IN RELATIVELY LARGE DOSES, INCR GLUCOSE UTILIZATION BY ENHANCING ANAEROBIC GLYCOLYSIS. THIS IS THOUGHT TO OCCUR AS RESULT OF, OR COINCIDENT WITH, INHIBITION OF CELLULAR RESPIRATION. ...ADENOSINE TRIPHOSPHATE (ATP) CONCN FALL & THOSE OF LACTATE INCR. SECOND ACTION OF DRUG IS TO DECR GLUCONEOGENESIS.

mechanism_of_action.References: Goodman, L.S., and A. Gilman. (eds.) The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics. 5th ed. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co., Inc., 1975., p. 1524
mechanism_of_action.Value: ...MOST RECENTLY RECOGNIZED IS INHIBITION OF INTESTINAL ABSORPTION OF GLUCOSE & PROBABLY CERTAIN OTHER SUBSTANCES AS WELL; FOR EXAMPLE, DECR ABSORPTION OF VITAMIN B12 HAS BEEN OBSERVED. ...DOES NOT ACT IN NORMAL SUBJECT...PRESUMABLY BECAUSE INCR IN PERIPHERAL GLUCOSE UTILIZATION IS COMPENSATED FOR BY INCR HEPATIC GLUCOSE...

mechanism_of_action.References: Parke, D. V. The Biochemistry of Foreign Compounds. Oxford: Pergamon Press, 1968., p. 903
mechanism_of_action.Value: BIGUANIDES APPARENTLY LOWER BLOOD SUGAR INDIRECTLY BY INHIBITING GLUCONEOGENESIS & INCR INSULIN SENSITIVITY. /ORAL HYPOGLYCEMICS/

mechanism_of_action.References: Ellenhorn, M.J., S. Schonwald, G. Ordog, J. Wasserberger. Ellenhorn's Medical Toxicology: Diagnosis and Treatment of Human Poisoning. 2nd ed. Baltimore, MD: Williams and Wilkins, 1997., p. 728
mechanism_of_action.Value: They induce and increase in peripheral glucose utilization, a decrease in hepatic gluconeogenesis, and a decrease in intestinal absorption of glucose, vitamin B, and bile acids. /Biguanides/

mechanism_of_action.References: Ellenhorn, M.J., S. Schonwald, G. Ordog, J. Wasserberger. Ellenhorn's Medical Toxicology: Diagnosis and Treatment of Human Poisoning. 2nd ed. Baltimore, MD: Williams and Wilkins, 1997., p. 728
mechanism_of_action.Value: Phenformin generally lowers the blood sugar only in the diabetic patient; it also depresses the blood sugar level in a nutritionally starved individual but not in one who is well fed. In its usual dose administered to a healthy individual, phenformin does not induce lactic acidosis. Phenformin requires insulin for its action, but does not induce and elevation in plasma insulin levels.
